chapter.title: User Guide
chapter.para: The User Guide provides an in-depth guide to working with Polarion. This "book" is mainly oriented to the tasks and operations that you perform while using Polarion. The first section introduces the major components of the user interface. This is followed by a section that covers the most common things most people need to do when working with projects. Later you will find "specialized" sections oriented toward the common tasks of specific types of users: Project Managers and Developers, for example. You can browse through the Table of Contents to see the organization of the various topics covered in the guide.

sect1.title: Quick Tour
sect1.para: This section of the User Guide provides a quick overview of the Polarion user interface.

textobject.phrase: The Polarion application (running in MS Internet Explorer)

caption.para: Polarion User Interface (Projects perspective, Dashboard topic)

sect1.para: Please refer to the above figure for the following sections.

sect2.title: Main Navigation Panel
sect2.para: This panel occupies the left side of the Polarion application. It provides the first level of navigation of the Polarion system. The panel has main types of components:

listitem.para: Navigation Portlets: Subsections of a panel or screen, portlets prevent some formatted view of data or information. In the case of the Main Navigation Panel, navigation portlets provide clickable links that help you access specific information in the system. The actual portlets that appear in the panel vary according to which perspective is current.

Perspective Selectors: Polarion uses the concept of perspectives, similar to Microsoft Outlook. One or more perspectives are visible to you depending on permissions granted by the system administrator. For example, if you do not have Administrator rights (either global or project level), there will be no selector for the Administration perspective and that perspective will not be accessible for you.

sect2.title: The Working Area
sect2.para: As the name implies, this is the area where you will do most of your work in Polarion. The content of this area depends of a number of factors, including current perspective and selections in the Main Navigation Panel such as Project and Topic, and the view tab selection.

sect3.title: View tabs
sect3.para: The Working Area provides several Views which are accessed by clicking one of the tabs that appear at the top.

textobject.phrase: Shows the selector tabs for Working Area Views

sect3.title: Search Bar
sect3.para: What you see in the Working Area is the result of some system query, whether predefined and automated, or manually defined and executed by you. Each of the View tabs displays the Search bar (see figure above). This bar displays the search query criteria that provide the view you are currently seeing. There are controls in the bar for changing the various criteria and executing the revised query, thus obtaining different information in the View.
Depending on the View that is current, the Search Bar may contain other controls such as a button or action list.

sect3.title: Work Item Selection and Detail panes
sect3.para: Please refer to the following figure for the next sections:

textobject.phrase: Shows the Work Item selection pane and the Work Item detail pane of the Working Area.

caption.para: Work Item Selection and Detail panes in the Working Area of the Polarion application

sect4.title: Work Item Selection pane
sect4.para: This pane enables you to select a Work Item for reading, editing or some other applicable operation (Print, for example). Depending on the current View, you may be able to select multiple Work Items (as in Bulk Edit, for example). The layout of this area (Table, Tree, Matrix, ect.) varies according to the current View tab.

sect4.title: Work Item Detail pane
sect4.para: Here you have access to all information about the selected Work Item(s). You need to scroll the pane to browse all available information. The pane provides a summary of the Work Item at the top. Scrolling down reveals a number of portlets that provide specific kinds of information and data.

The toolbar for this pane provides buttons for a number of common operations you can perform on the selected item(s) Edit or Watch, for example. Other buttons provide quick jumps to commonly needed detail portlets such as Comments, Links, and Attachments.

note.title: A note about editing
note.para: The Detail pane is where you can edit the selected item. ( In Polarion Enterprise Edition you can edit multiple items in Multi-edit view). Your ability to edit Work Items depends on the role and access rights assigned you by the system administrator. If you do not have write access privileges, the buttons and links that trigger edit mode do not appear, or are disabled in the interface.

sect1.title: Getting Started with Projects
sect1.para: This section will give you the basics about creating and accessing Projects in Polarion.

sect2.title: Creating Projects
sect2.para: To create a new project you must have global Administrator rights. The information in this section assumes that you already have a Subversion repository in which you can create a new folder for the new Project.
There are 2 basic scenarios for creating a Project:

listitem.para: Create a new empty Project from a Project Template. This creates a new folder in your repository.
Mark an existing repository folder as a Project.

sect3.title: Creating a new Project from a template
sect3.para: Polarion comes with a default Project Template Empty Project. You can create copies of this template and customize them to create new projects templates, but for now let's concentrate on the default a new project based on the Empty Project template.

para.emphasis: To create a new Empty Project:

listitem.para: Log into Polarion and click Administration in the perspective selector (bottom of the left navigation).
In the Projects portlet, click Repository.
In the Topics portlet, expand the Projects node and click the Projectssub-node. A table of currently defined Projects loads in the Working Area.
Go to the Projects table displayed in the Working Area and click the Create New Project button.
The following controls appear in the Working Area:

textobject.phrase: View of the new project wizard screen for a new empty project

listitem.para: Fill in the fields as follows:
Project ID: Enter a unique identifier for the project. This value identifies the new Project in the Polarion project database.

Template: Select the desired template in the drop-down list. By default, there will be only the Empty Project template available. If your administrator has added other project templates to the system, these will appear in the drop-down list.
Path: Enter a name for the root folder of the new project.
Click the Next button. The following appears in the Working Area:

textobject.phrase: View of the new project wizard screen for a new empty project

listitem.para: In the Project Name field, enter a name for the new Project. This is the name that will appear in the list of projects in the Projects
Click the Create button to finish the operation and create the new Project and empty project folder in the repository.

sect3.title: Creating a new project by marking an existing repository folder
sect3.para: You many not always want to create a new Project in Polarion "from scratch". For example, you may have an existing folder structure in your Subversion repository that you want to start managing with Polarion. In this case, you need to specify the root folder and tell Polarion to "mark" it as a project folder.

para.emphasis: To create a new Project from an existing repository folder tree:

listitem.para: Log into Polarion and click Administration in the perspective selector (bottom of the left navigation. Recall that you must have global Administrator rights to access the Administration perspective.)
In the Projects portlet, click Repository.
In the Topics portlet, expand the Projects node and click the Projectssub-node. A table of currently defined Projects loads in the Working Area.
Go to the Projects table displayed in the Working Area and click the Mark Folder as Project button.
The following controls appear in the Working Area:

textobject.phrase: View of the new project wizard screen for a new project based on an existing folder

caption.para: New project specification: specify the existing folder to mark as Project

listitem.para: The repository root path appears to the left of an edit box. In the edit box, type the repository path to the folder you want to mark as being a Project folder. Use forward slashes (/) to separate subfolders.

example.title: Repository Root Path
example.para: Given a repository root path of http://ourdomain.com/repos/, and an existing subfolder projects/java/someproject, your entry would look something like:

listitem.para: Click the Mark button to create the project based on the specified root folder.

sect2.title: Accessing Projects
sect2.para: All users have read access to Projects in Polarion. You may have write (change) as well depending on your role on your team.

listitem.para: Log in to Polarion.
If you are not already in the Projects perspective, click the Projects perspective selector.
Select the Project you want to access in the Projects portlet.

sect2.para: If you have just logged in, you will be taken to the Dashboard Topic and the Project's Dashboards will load in the Working Area. If you change Projects, the newly selected Project opens with the same Topic (e.g. Dashboard).

sect3.title: Accessing Project documents
sect3.para: To access documents of the current project, expand the relevant Project node in the Projects portlet and select the documents folder. The repository URL to the documents folder appears in the Working Area. You can use this URL with the SVN command line or a SVN client to checkout the documents folder. If documents exist in the documents folder, a table listing them appears beneath the URL in the Working Area.

note.title: Enterprise Edition Note
note.para: While you can store documents in the project repository in all Polarion editions, you can only edit them "live" in Polarion Enterprise Edition. For more information see Working with Live Documents.

sect3.title: Accessing Project Work Items
sect3.para: "Work Item" is a general term applied to anything that needs to be worked on. Work Items include Requirements, Tasks, Change Requests, Tests, and Defects.
For basic access to Work Items, click the Work Items topic in the Topics portlet when the relevant Project is selected in the Projects portlet.

sect4.title: Work Item Views
sect4.para: The Working Area presents several views on Work Items. These appear as a tab set:

textobject.phrase: Shows the Work Item view tabs in the Working Area

caption.para: Work Item view tabs in the Working Area

sect4.para: The names of the tabs describe the format or functionality of the views.

listitem.para: Table: Displays a table of Work Items accessed by the current navigation selection and/pr query.
Tree: Displays a table of Work Items accessed by the current navigation selection and/or Search query in a tree structure that shows related Work Items up to 10 levels deep.
Live Plan: Presents a Live Plan of just the Work Items accessed by the current navigation selection and/or search query. You can select a Work Item in the chart and edit it in the detail area.
Road Map: Presents a table of Work Items selected by the current navigation and/or search query. You can further filter the selection according to Time Point.

Matrix: Enables you to trace links between Work Items. You create two system queries: one for Rows and one for Columns of the matrix. With the search results you can specify the relationship you want to see in the results: dependency, duplication, relativity, etc.
Multi Edit: Places all Work Items in the current navigation or query selection into edit mode in which the main data fields can be edited.
Bulk Edit: Presents a single editor pane in which you can edit Work Item fields and apply your changes to all the work items currently selected by the current navigation or search query.

sect4.title: Using queries and shortcuts
sect4.para: You can use queries and Shortcuts to filter the list of Work Items.

listitem.para: You can filter the Work Item view for a particular type of Work Item by clicking on the one of the sub-topics of the Work Items topic ( in the Topics portlet).
You can use certain Shortcuts in the Shortcuts portlet to filter the list of Work Items. For example, the My Work Items shortcut limits the display to only Work Items assigned to you.

You can further refine any view with a query. The parameters of the current query are always shown beneath the view tabs. You can use any of the controls to customize the current query to further filter the Work Items shown.

tip.para: You can save the results of any query and the current state of a view as a Shortcut by clicking the Save As Shortcut icon in the Search bar of the Working Area.
Saving a shortct stores the selected view tab, all query parts, table columns, and table sorting.
You can customize existing shortcuts with the Customize icon located on the title bar of the Shortcuts portlet.

sect2.title: Exporting to MS Project
sect2.para: Microsoft Project Export is a feature of Polarion Enterprise Edition only.
You can export an entire Project, or any subset of the Work Items comprising it, to various Microsoft formats, including MS Office Word, MS Office Excel, and Microsoft Project.

textobject.phrase: Shows the interaction and result of export to MS Project.

caption.para: Exporting a Project to Microsoft Project

listitem.para: Be sure you are working in the Project you want to export it should be selected in the Projects portlet in the left Main Navigation panel.

If you want to export the entire Project, select the Work Items node in the Topics portlet. If you want to export a subset of the Project, select an appropriate Shortcut in the Topics portlet or execute an appropriate saved query or custom query built with the Query Builder (accessed in the Working Area's Search bar).
Click the Operations action button and select Export in the action menu. A browser popup window appears.
Select the desired target format, character set, and use the checkboxes in the data columnns list to choose which data you want to export.

Click the Download button and choose the location to save the data file on your local system. The selected data is saved in an appropriate XML format which you can subsequently open in the relevant Microsoft application.

sect3.title: Opening the exported file in MS Project
sect3.para: The xml file that is created as a result of the Export to MS Project action should not be renamed with a .mpp extension before opening it in MS Project.
There are 2 ways to open the exported file in MS Project:

listitem.para: Using Windows Explorer context menu
Using MS Project File menu

para.emphasis: To open the exported file using Windows Explorer:

listitem.para: Selecting the exported file in Windows Explorer
Right-click on the file and choose Open in on the context menu, followed by MS Project on the submenu;

sect3.para: To open the exported file from MS Project:

listitem.para: Open MS Project.
Open the Open File dialog.
Choose xml format, select the xml file, and click Open.
Choose the As new project option.

sect1.title: Work Item Basics
sect1.para: This section provides and introduction to the basics of handling Work Items in Polarion.

sect2.title: Work Item Types
sect2.para: A Work Item is the Polarion term for an artifact of the development process that is waiting to be implemented, is in progress, or has been implemented. The default types of Work Items are:

listitem.para: Requirement
Task
Change Request
Defect

sect2.para: Work Item types are user defined. The default types can be changed and/or new types can be defined by an Administrator. For more information, see Configuring Enumerations in the Administrator's Guide.
Using the respective data fields for the purpose, a Work Item can be assigned to someone, and incorporated into Project planning and tracking..

sect2.title: Browsing and Searching Work Items
sect2.para: Every Work Item is part of a Project, and is planned and tracked with the Project. If a Work Item has dependencies with another project, it is possible to show this using the Link feature.

You can browse the Work Items in any project in different Views (tabs) in the Working Area: Table, Tree, Live Plan, Matrix, etc. Some Views are mainly just listings while others show relationships to time (Live Plan) or other items (Tree, Matrix).
To browse Work Items, select the Project in the Projects list of the Projects perspective, the select the tab for the desired view in the Working Area.

When you select a Work Item, its detail appears in the lower half of the Working Area and different portlets in that pane display information about the Work Item such as priority, status, who it's assigned to, when it is (or was) started, when it will be (or was) completed, etc.

sect3.title: Searching
sect3.para: Polarion provides robust query-based searching. Every View and every data display is actually the result of some underlying query. There are a number of predefined queries that you can use to quickly locate and isolate a subset of all the Work Items in a Project. These are saved as Shortcuts, which appear in the Shortcuts portlet (main Navigation panel). Shortcuts are unique in that they are a combination of a View and a query. For example, a Shortcut might access a set up Work Items and show them in the Tree view. You can create your own Search queries and save them as Shortcuts.
Each View tab in the Working displays a Search bar that you can use to create Search queries to locate the Work Items you want to see. An example is shown in the following figure:

textobject.phrase: Shows the Search bar in the Tree view of the Working Area.

caption.para: Search bar (as it appears in the Tree view)

sect4.title: Using the Query Builder
sect4.para: Search queries can range from simple to complex depending on what subset of Work Items you want to find. If you need something that is not provided by the default Views and Shortcuts, you can create a custom Search query using the Query Builder feature which enables you to build complex queries visually.
You can access the Query Builder from the and field of the Search bar. Drop down the list and select the Query Builder item in the list.

textobject.phrase: Shows how to access the Query Builder.

caption.para: How to access the Query Builder

sect3.title: Stored and shared queries
sect3.para: Queries are what fetches the Work Items that display in the Work Item tables and other views. Useful queries can be saved and reused in several ways. As mentioned in Shortcuts, your most commonly reused queries can be saved as Shortcuts to make them accessible from the Shortcuts portlet. But you can store and share other queries which are accessible from the Search bar's and field. Queries can be global in scope or limited to the scope of one Project or even just yourself as a user.

sect4.title: Accessing stored/shared queries
sect4.para: The drop-down list in the Search bar's and field provides access to all currently saved/shared queries.

textobject.phrase: Shows the access to stored/shared queries for all scopes.

sect2.title: Creating and Editing Work Items
sect2.para: This section provides a quick overview on how to create a new Work Item and how to edit an existing Work Item.

sect3.title: Creating New Work Items
sect3.para: Work Items can be created in the system in two ways:

listitem.para: Manually
Using Live Documents

sect3.para: This section discusses manual creation. For information about Live Documents see Working with Live Documents.

para.emphasis: To create a new Work Item

listitem.para: Make sure you are working in the Projects perspective, and have selected the Project the new Work Item should belong to in the Projects portlet.
In the Topics portlet, click the Work Items node.
In the Working Area, select the Table view. A table of the currently existing Work Items in this Project appears in the upper half of the Working Area.
In the Working Area, click the Create action button, and select the type of Work Item you want to create from the drop-down menu.
Follow the next sequence of screens (similar to a "wizard") to create the new Work Item.

sect3.title: Editing Work Items
sect3.para: You can edit existing Work Items either singly or several at a time (Bulk Edit). The latter is useful for such tasks as assigning multiple Work Items to the same person, or setting the same status, priority, or start/end date for several items.

sect4.title: Editing multiple Work Items at once
sect4.para: The Bulk Edit view tab in the Working Area enables you to select multiple Work Items and edit them as a unit. When you save the changes, the field values are applied to all selected Work Items.

The Work Items that appear in the Bulk Edit view vary according to the current system query. You can use Shortcuts, saved or custom Search queries to isolate or narrow the subset of Work Items you want to edit all at once.

para.emphasis: To selected and edit multiple Work Items:

listitem.para: Make sure you are working in the correct Project, and in the Work Items topic in that project.
Select the Bulk Edit view tab in the Work Area. A table of Work Items appears in the upper pane. The list of Work Items Depends on the current system query.
Use shortcuts or the Search feature (including the Query Builder if needed) so that the results contain all the Work Items you want to edit.
The leftmost columnn of Work Items table now contains a checkbox. Check this box for each Work Item you want to edit.

tip.para: You can select or deselect all the items in the table by checking or clearing the checkbox in the header of this columnn.

listitem.para: Go to the Work Item detail pane (lower half of the Working Area). Check the box next to each field you want to edit, then change the field value as desired. If the field is not available for Bulk Edit, the checkbox next to the field is disabled and you will not be able to change the field value.
Click the Submit button to save your changes and apply them to all the selected Work Items.

textobject.phrase: Shows the Work Item selection for Bulk Edit, and the single editor for all selected items.

note.para: Linked Work Items do not appear in the list of items in Bulk Edit, but you still can use Bulk Edit to remove linked Work Items by entering the ID of a linked Work Item in the input field of the Linked Work Items portlet and clicking on the - (minus) icon. You can use the "Workitem Picker" (by pressing [select]) to find the Work Item if you don't remember its ID.

sect4.title: Using Multi Edit View
sect4.para: The Multi Edit view also enable you to edit multiple work items, but it differs from Bulk Edit. With Bulk Edit, you have a single editor pane and changes are applied to multiple Work Items. With Multi Edit, all Work Items accessed by the current system query are editable in a single editor space in the Work Area. You edit a single Work Item at a time, but all items are editable and changes to multiple items can be saved all at once. You can edit the main data fields in this view, but not everything. For example, you can't create links or edit watchers.
Multi Edit is a feature of Polarion for Subversion Enterprise Edition.

sect2.title: Common Operations with Work Items
sect2.para: This section covers several common things that people need to do with Work Items.

sect3.title: Assigning a Work Item
sect3.para: You assign a Work Item to a person using the Assignee field in the Work Item detail. This field presents a drop-down list of all Polarion users. You assign the selected Work Item (or Items, if working in Bulk Edit view) by selecting the user's name from the list. Note that the assignee must have an account on your Polarion system in order to appear in the Assignee list. (It can be easy to omit setting up accounts for e.g. a domain expert who is not on the engineering team but who needs to be assigned a Requirement.)

sect3.title: Changing a Work Item's status
sect3.para: You can initiate a change of status for a selected Work Item directly in the detail pane without entering Edit mode. The Status field has a drop-down list that displays a choice of Workflow Actions. These are configured by the Polarion administrator and are what actually changes the status value of the item according to the configured status and status transition definitions. (See Administrator's Guide: Workflow) for more information.

Selecting a new Workflow Action (Resolve and Close, for example), triggers Edit mode, where you can add a comment, set a value for Resolution, edit linked Work Items, etc. When you click the Update, the Workflow Action sets the appropriate status value which subsequently appears in the user interface.

sect3.title: Setting Planning Constraints
sect3.para: The Planning constraint field enables you to fix the planned start or end date for a Work Item. The date you specify is reflected in the Live Plan.

textobject.phrase: Shows the Planning Constraint field and popup date picker

caption.para: Planning constraint field and popup date picker

important.para: You will not see relevant planning results for unassigned and unestimated Work Items.

sect4.title: Planned items in the Live Plan
sect4.para: When the Planning Constraint and Due Date fields are set, the Work Item spans the defined time period in the Live Plan view. The popup detail (when you click on the Work Item in the Live Plan view) includes Planned Start Date and Planned End Date and Remaining Information.

sect3.title: Printing a Work Item
sect3.para: You can print one or multiple selected Work Items to any printer to which your computer has access. You can select a single Work Item for printing in the Table, Tree, Live Plan, or Road Map views. You can select multiple Work Items for print in the Bulk Edit view.

listitem.para: Select the Work Item(s) you want to print in the appropriate view.
Locate the action button labeled Operations and click it to drop down a menu of actions.
Choose Print in the Operations action list.
Your system print dialog appears. Choose the target printer in this dialog, set desired print job properties if your print dialog provides this functionality, and launch the print job.

sect2.title: Linking Work Items
sect2.para: Linking Work Items is the key to being able to take advantage of Polarion Enterprise Edition's Traceability and Impact Analysis features. Your team should plan and follow a process of linking Work Items from the outset.

Generally speaking, you want to create links from Requirements to the Tasks and/or Change Requests that fulfill them, and also links from Tasks/Change Requests to the repository revision in which they are implemented. By doing this, your team will have several key advantages with Polarion:

listitem.para: Possibility to trace from Requirements to the Work Items and code that fulfill them

Possibility to backtrace from e.g. defective code (in a repository revision) to the Tasks/Change Requests that implemented the defective code, and from those to the Requirement that called for the functionality.
Possibility to assess the impact (and by extension, the cost) of a changed Requirement by seeing all the artifacts that would be affected by the change.
Possibility to view and analyze various relationships between Work Items such as dependency, relatedness, parent-child, duplication, and follow-up.

sect2.para: This section describes the basic techniques for creating Links. There are basically 3 ways to do it:

listitem.para: Create links while editing an individual Work Item.
Create links for multiple Work Items at once using Bulk Edit.
Create links using the Matrix View.

sect3.title: Linking individual Work Items
sect3.para: In the Work Item detail pane you can click the Links button to auto-scroll the view to the link portlets: Linked Repository Revisions and Linked Work Items. Use the small Add in either or these portlets to open the link editor in which you can select the revision or Work Item you want to link to the current Work Item.

textobject.phrase: Shows the portlets for link creation in read and edit modes

caption.para: Link portlets in read mode and edit mode.

sect3.title: Linking multiple Work Items at once
sect3.para: The technique in Bulk Edit is the same as for single Work Items (see previous screenshot). The same portlets exist in the bulk editor. The difference is that you can create the same link(s) to multiple selected Work Items in a single operation.

sect3.title: Using the Matrix view to create and browse links
sect3.para: Traceability Analysis is a feature of Polarion Enterprise Edition only.

The Matrix view provides a robust way to both create and browse links. The matrix is populated with 2 subsets of Work Items, one for matrix rows, and one for columnns. Each subset is built with a query in the special dual version of the Search bar. Each query can access either Work Items or repository revisions, so the matrix can show links between Work Items only, or between Work Items and repository revisions. Work Item queries can also filter for link Role- "depends on" or "related to", for example.

When the matrix has been populated, the intersection of each row and columnn shows if there is an existing link between the items in that row/column, and provides the possibility to create one if none currently exists. Existing links show and arrow in the intersection indicating the direction of the link. Clicking on the intersection pops up details about the link.

textobject.phrase: Shows the Matrix view with dual Search queries and link details.

caption.para: Matrix view showing dual Search queries and popup link details

sect3.para: Refer to the screenshot below when following the procedure to create a link using the Matrix view:

textobject.phrase: Shows the toolbar and matrix in mode for link creation

caption.para: Matrix toolbar in link creation mode

para.emphasis: To create a link in the Matrix view:

listitem.para: Populate the rows and columnns of the matrix by building queries that will display the source and target Work Items (or Work Items and repository revisions) in the matrix rows and columnns.
Toggle Link mode by clicking the Link Mode button in the toolbar (see screenshot).
In the Role combobox, select a role for the link.
Select the directionality of the link using the Direction buttons.

tip.para: You can do this step either before or after creating the link in the matrix (see next step).

listitem.para: Locate the intersection of the Work Items you want to link (or the Work Item and the repository revision you want to link, and click on that cell. A green arrow appears in the cell showing the directionality of the link. The actual link is not yet created.
Click the Submit to create the link. The green arrow in the cell changes to black.

sect3.title: How Links are handled in Live Plan
sect3.para: There are 2 kinds of links recognized by the Live Plan feature: depends and parent. The planning.xml file in Administration assigns existing Work Item link roles to these two categories. (Links with roles which are of neither the depends nor the parent kind are ignored by Live Plan).

sect4.title: Dependencies
sect4.para: The dependent Work Item always links to the one it depends on. For example, if A depends on B, then A holds the link: B <-- A. This kind of link ensures that A does not start before B ends. However, this does not influence the planning of B. Consider the situation when High priority task A depends on Low priority task B. Task A will be planned after task B.

sect4.title: Parents
sect4.para: Children always link to the parent. Therefore the 'contains' link role should not be used; the 'parent' role with the opposite direction should be used instead. The Live Plan always shows only the leaf nodes of the containment hierarchy. for example, if Requirement has child Tasks, then just the Tasks are shown, not the Requirement. The parent's planned start/end are calculated as the minimum/maximum of its children's planned starts/ends values. The Remaining/Initial Estimate value of the parent are not taken into account in this case.

sect2.title: Exporting Work Items
sect2.para: You can export one or multiple selected Work Items to an office document (MS Word or MS Excel). You can select a single Work Item for export in the Table, Tree, Live Plan, or Road Map views. You can select multiple Work Items for export in the Bulk Edit view.

para.emphasis: To export Work Items to a document:

listitem.para: Select the Work Item(s) you want to export in the appropriate view.
Locate the action button labeled Operations and click it to drop down a menu of actions.
Choose Export in the Operations action list.
Specify the type of document and the local path for saving it

note.title: Note about exported documents
note.para: Documents created by export are not Live Documents, nor are they automatically added to the repository- they are just documents stored on your local system. You cannot edit exported documents in Polarion or track and manage them in Polarion unless you explicitly add them to a Subversion repository managed with Polarion.

sect1.title: Managing Requirements
sect1.para: This chapter covers Polarion's Requirements Management features and functionality, including the exclusive Live Documents feature.

sect2.title: Overview of Capabilities
sect2.para: Polarion supports the 3 typical phases of the Requirements engineering process:

listitem.para: Inception
Discussion/revision
Approval

sect2.para: Typically, managers and domain experts who define requirements prefer to work from the basis of office documents such as Microsoft Word documents or Microsoft Excel worksheets. However, the Engineering side needs a database-driven solution to be able to manage the complexity of their work. Traditionally, one or the other, or both of these equally essential team components were forced to compromise for a less-than-optional solution. Either domain experts were forced to learn an unfamiliar software system which did not support their mental model in order to write up Requirements, or engineers were forced to deal with document-based requirements and the resulting inefficiencies (for them).

Polarion provides a workable compromise for both sets of stakeholders through its unique Live Document technology. Managers and other domain experts can, at their option, work with familiar office documents to author requirements. Using special Live Document templates provided with Polarion, authors' Requirements are automatically recognized by Polarion, and relevant Work Items are created in the system. The Engineering side can use all the features of Polarion to track and manage the Work Items. Any changes made to the Work Items are automatically reflected in the relevant Live Document. This facilitates the review/approval process, as the Requirements authors, managers, domain experts, etc. can review the Live Document (which they can download and read locally). If they in turn make changes to the Requirements, by checking the Live Document in to Polarion, new Work Items are created, and existing Work Items are updated automatically. In this way, all stakeholders in the Requirements Engineering and Management process can work with the tools and in the environments that make them most productive.

sect2.title: Inception Phase
sect2.para: This phase will typically involve 2 main activities:

listitem.para: Creating a new Requirement in the system
Creating and editing Live Documents

sect3.title: Creating a New Requirement in the System
sect3.para: The starting point of the Requirement process is to create a new Requirement in the relevant Project of your Polarion syste. Once defines, you can creae Work Items either manually in the system, or by updloading a Live Document based on a Live Document template.
To create and edit Requirements, you need to be working in the Projects perspective. Select the relevant Project in the Projects portlet.

listitem.para: If necessary, select the tab for the Table view in the work area.
Click the Create and select Requirement in the drop-down menu.
The work item editor opens in the lower part of the work area with the fields for a new Requirement.
Enter relevant information in the fields. Note that only Title, Priority, and Severity are required. Description is recommended for clarity.

tip.para: Your system configuration may have other required fields. Required fields are marked with a red asterisk (*) next to the field label.

listitem.para: In the work item editor Toolbar, click the Create button to

sect4.title: Creating Work Items for a New Requirement
sect4.para: After creating a new Requirement, there are 2 ways to create Work Items that relate to it.

listitem.para: Work Items can be created individually in the Polarion system. Link new Work Items to the relevant Requirement either singly, or all at once using the Bulk Edit feature.
Work Items can be created automatically from a Live Document attached to the Requirement. Working with Live Documents is covered in the next section.

sect3.title: Working with Live Documents
sect3.para: Live Document is a feature of Polarion Enterprise Edition only.

Polarion's Live Document technology enables those team members who prefer to work with office documents to define requirements using MS Word and/or MS Excel with special Live Document templates provided with Polarion. When attached to a Requirement in the Polarion system, Work Items are automatically created from the Live Document(s). Revisions to Work Items automatically propagate back to the relevant Live Document, and revisions to a Live Document automatically create new Work Items or update existing ones.

Live Document templates are provided in the Polarion system installation on the server. There is one template for MS Word and one for MS Excel. This section explains the basic process for creating, editing, and saving Live Documents built with Live Document templates.

note.title: Required Version of Microsoft Office
note.para: The Live Documents feature works only with Microsoft Office 2003 Professional. Earlier versions of Microsoft Office, and MS Office 2003 Basic do NOT work with Polarion's Live Documents feature.

sect4.title: Creating a New Live Document
sect4.para: In order to create a Live Document, a folder named documents must exist in the Project. This folder should be created by the user who has administration permissions for creating Projects. Once you have a Project containing the documents folder, it is simple to create a new Live Document.

para.emphasis: To create a new Live Document:

listitem.para: Select the documents folder in the Projects portlet. The work area displays the repository URL of the folder and a list of existing documents, if any.
Click the New Document button in the work area. The work area displays headers for two options:
To create a new document from a template, enter a name in the Document Name field, and choose a template in the Template list.
Click the Submit button to create the new document. in the system (i.e. not locally.

sect4.title: Viewing the New Live Document
sect4.para: After creating a new Live Document, you can select it in the documents folder. (Click the Refresh icon in the Projects portlet's title bar if you don't immediately see the new Live Document.)
When selected, two topics in the Topics portlet: Overview, and Work Items. The Overview topic is selected automatically by default.

sect4.title: Opening a New Live Document for Editing
sect4.para: You can either edit the new Live Document directly from the repository, or download a copy to your local repository and edit locally. If you are constantly connected, the direct method is simplest.

para.emphasis: To open and edit a Live Document directly:

listitem.para: Select the document in the documents folder.
Select the Overview topic in the Topics portlet.

In the work area, click the Edit in Word or Edit in Excel button, depending on which type of document the selected Live Document is. You will be prompted for your login details to authorize opening of the document.

sect4.para: The Live Document opens in the relevant MS Office application in a new instance of your browser. You can edit the document and save changes just as if you were editing a local copy. Changes will be reflected in the Polarion system after you close the document.

para.emphasis: To edit a New Live document locally:

listitem.para: Select the document in the documents folder.
Select the Overview topic in the Topics portlet.
In the work area, the document's repository URL displays in the URL field.
Use your Subversion client program, or the Subversion command line interface to checkout the document at the displayed URL. This will obtain a local copy of the document.
Open the local copy in the relevant MS Office application and edit as you would any document.

sect2.title: Revision Phase
sect2.para: Once Requirements have been defined and relevant Work Items created initially, there is typically a phase of review, discussion, and revision of Requirements with stakeholders from both domain experts and engineering involved. Polarion supports this process with its Live Document technology. As in the initial definition phase, stakeholders can modify requirements in their preferred environment: an office document, or the Polarion repository. This section explains how to modify existing Requirements in both ways.

sect3.title: Revising requirements using Live Documents
sect3.para: To modify Requirements using an office document, it is necessary to locate the relevant Live Document in the Polarion system, check it out of the repository, change the document, and check the changed document in to the repository. On check-in, any new Work Items defined in the document are automatically created in Polarion, and existing Work Items are updated with any changes in the document.

para.emphasis: To locate a Live Document to be modified:

listitem.para: In the Polarion web interface, make sure you are working in the Projects perspective. Switch to this perspective if necessary.
Using the Projects portlet, locate the Project for which the desired Live Document contains Requirements.

Expand the Project node (click [+] and select the documents folder. A list of documents for this Project loads in the work area. The list should contain the Live Document with the Requirements you want to modify. Nodes for each document appear as children of the documents folder in the Projects portlet.
In the Projects portlet, select the Live Document you want to modify. Details for the document appear in the work area.

tip.para: You can compare document versions by clicking on the Revisions table in the document Overview page.

sect4.title: Checking out a Live Document for Editing
sect4.para: If you are working on line, the checkout process is as simple as clicking the Edit in Word or the Edit in Excel button in the work area above the details of the selected Live Document. Polarion Polarion automatically handles the repository checkout process and displays the document in the relevant office application running in a new instance of your web browser. You can work on the document normally.

important.para: In order for this feature to work, you must set your Internet Explorer browser settings to initialize and script ActiveX controls not marked as safe (more below).

para.emphasis: To set this option in Internet Explorer:

listitem.para: On the Internet Explorer main menu, choose Tools | Internet Options.
Click the Security tab.
Click the Trusted Sites icon. The Sites button is enabled.

Click the Sites button. In the field Add this Web site to the Zone, enter the URL of the root of your Polarion system. For example, the root of the Polarion hosted version is: http://powerversion.com/polarion/portal.
Click the Add to add the URL to the list of Trusted Sites.

If you do not access your Polarion system with https: protocol, and if the checkbox Require server verification (https:) for all sites in this zone is checked, uncheck it. If you have other sites in this zone and you want to require https: for all sites, click Cancel, skip the rest of these steps and see the Note below.
Click OK to close the Trusted Sites dialog.
In the Internet Options dialog, click Custom Level.
Scroll down the list of options until you locate Initialize and script ActiveX controls not marked as safe.

If you are setting this option for the Trusted Sites zone, you can choose the Enable option if you don't want to be prompted whenever you edit a Live Document, or the Prompt option if you prefer a prompt.
Click OK to close the Security Settings dialog, and again in the Internet Options dialog.

note.title: If you require https: in your Trusted Zone
note.para: If you require https: for all sites in your Trusted Zone, and you do not access your Polarion system via the internet using https: protocol, then you can locate the option in the Security Settings dialog and choose the Prompt option. You will then get a prompt whenever you edit Live Documents from the Polarion web interface, in which case you should allow the initialization and scripting of the ActiveX.

sect4.para: If you need to work on the document off line, you need to checkout the document from the Subversion repository. Use a Subversion client such as TortoiseSVN, or the Subversion command line interface according to your preference or your organization's established procedure. The URL of the Live Document is shown in the work area in the URL field when the Live Document is selected in the documents folder.

sect4.title: Checking In an Edited Live Document
sect4.para: If editing the document on line in the office application running in your browser, simply save your changes and close the document. Polarion takes care of the repository checkin process.
If you have edited a checked out local copy of the Live Document, use your Subversion client or the Subversion command line interface to check the document in to the repository.

In both cases, Polarion will create Work Items in the system if the checked in document defines new Requirements, and it will update existing Work Items if the relevant Requirement has been modified in the Live Document.

note.para: if you change only one Work Item in a Live Document, all Work Items from that document will have their Last Update field changed to the date of the update of the single item.

sect2.title: Approval Phase
sect2.para: Polarion supports a process of approval for Requirements. Work Itemspertaining to Requirements are approved/disapproved using Polarion (i.e. not in a Live Document). Each Work Item can be marked as Awaiting Approval, Approved, or Disapproved (either singly, or in aggregate using the Bulk Edit feature), and assigned one or more "approver(s)" - user(s) having responsibility for reviewing and approving or disapproving the Work Item(s). Approvers can quickly access all the Work Items assigned to them for approval using a special pre-defined filter named Awaiting my approval.

tip.para: Project managers should make sure that approvers who may not have user accounts in the Polarion system as a result of the Requirements definition/modification process are set up with accounts for the approval phase so they can access the Work Items they must review.

sect3.title: Assigning Approver(s) to Work Items
sect3.para: One or more approvers can be assigned to each Work Item of a Requirement any time after the Work Item is created in the Polarion system. Be sure that everyone in the organization who must review/approve requirements has a user account before assigning approvers to Work Items.

para.emphasis: To assign approver(s) to a Work Item:

listitem.para: Select a Work Item in the Work Items table in the upper part of the work area. The Work Item detail editor loads in the lower part of the work area.
Scroll the detail pane until you locate the Approvers section. Initially there is one approver line present in the section which has no assignment attributes set.
In the first Approvers line, select Awaiting Approval in the Status drop-down list. This marks the start of the approval process for this Work Item.
Assign the item to an approver by selecting a user name from the User drop-down list.
If you wish to assign another approver to this Work Item, click the green plus sign at the right side of the current line. Another line is added to the Approvers section below the previous line.
Repeat the foregoing steps for this and any more approvers you want to assign to the current Work Item.

tip.para: Use the Bulk Edit feature to assign the same approver(s) to multiple Work Items at once. The steps are essentially the same as just described, only the edit is applied to all selected Work Items.

sect3.title: Approving or Disapproving Work Items
sect3.para: If you are assigned review/approval responsibility for Requirements, you need to use the Polarion system to mark Work Items as approved or disapproved. You can review the Work Items in a Live Document but you need to use Polarion to mark Work Items as approved or disapproved.

sect4.title: Locating the Work Items You Must Review
sect4.para: Locating the Work Items for which you are assigned as an approver is quick and easy. There is a pre-defined filter named Awaiting my approval that will aggregate all the relevant Work Items for a selected Requirement.

para.emphasis: To locate Work Items awaiting your approval:

listitem.para: Navigate to the Requirement item or document in the relevant Project and select it. A list of all pertinent Work Items appears in the Work Items table at the top of the work area.
Select the Tree view (tab in the top part of the work area)
In the Search bar set the selection criteria as follows:

sect4.para: The list of Work Items updates to contain only those Work Items assigned to you for approval.

sect4.title: Marking a Work Item as Approved or Disapproved
sect4.para: When a Work Item is selected in the Work Items table, the detail appears in the lower part of the work area. Click the Edit button to enter Edit mode. You can now edit all fields in the Work Item detail.
Scroll the detail area until you find the Approvers section, which should contain at least one line displaying your Polarion user name.

To mark this Work Item as approved or disapproved, select the relevant value in the Status drop-down list. If there are multiple lines for different approvers, be sure you set the status on the line containing your user name.

tip.para: With Polarion Enterprise Edition you can use the Multi Edit view to set the same status value for multiple Work Items assigned to a selected user all at the same time.

sect2.title: About Live Document Templates
sect2.para: Polarion comes with one pre-defined Requirements template for MS Word and one for MS Excel. It is possible to customize these templates, or, probably better, create customized copies of the original templates provided with by installation.
Templates are stored in the Subversion repository folder: /.polarion/tracker/document_templates.

To modify or create copies of the templates, you should checkout the repository folder to your local system. Edit template files using the relevant MS Office application and commit new/changed files to the repository. Any new templates will appear in the Template list during the process of creating a new Live Document.

sect3.title: Working with Local Files
sect3.para: It is possible to save local copies of Requirements templates and create new local Requirements documents off line that are based on a local template file. Then, when creating a new Live Document in Polarion, instead of choosing the option to create a new live document from a template,you choose instead the option to upload a file. Use the Browse button to locate the local file to be uploaded into the Polarion system. After uploading a new document created locally, you will need to use the button Assign IDs to cause the Work Items in the document to be assigned system IDs in Polarion so that they will be searchable, etc. in the system.
You can save documents either with the office application's file extension (.doc or .xls, or the extension .xml.
As with documents created using the on line interface, Work Items are created from the document content after upload. (In the case of modified documents, existing Work Items are updated.)
